data.author: Morgan Jones

data.text: Depends on your size, how comfortable you want to be and what your budget is... Rab Ridge Raider hooped bivvy is breathable and reduces condensation whilst being a large bivvy. The issue is the way you have to get in and out from the top only. Snugpak Stratosphere is durable and again fairly large hooped bivvy but with the benefit of a side opening that goes 3/4 of the way down. Much easier to get in/out of but if you don't leave the vents fully open condensation can be an issue. The best for me is a Snugpak Ionosphere which is basically between a tent/bivvy. Very spacious yet stealthy. Zero condensation in my experience. I have both Ionosphere and Stratosphere and both have worked well for me. I'll pop a couple of pics up so you can see. Others have mentioned Dutch army bivvy bags and while they are great they can be very warm in the summer. Gore Tex is quite thick. Rab eVent material in my opinion is as breathable as Gore Tex but is lighter so not as hot in the heat... Rab Ridge Raider costs twice as much as most bivvy bags though.

data.author: Neil Hamilton-Meikle

data.text: Bivvy bags are fun, and it's nice to have a very simple place to sleep, but if you want to be comfortable (i.e. dry, free of midges or other pests, have a dry surface to sleep on and put your bags on, somewhere dry to dress and pack in the morning etc) then a light tent is better, easier to pitch, doesn't have the same condensation issues, and has no weight penalty once you add a tarp to a bivvy bag. I have both systems, and sometimes use the bivvy bag for a short nap, or a different experience - so I am not saying don't get one. Just be aware that it might not be a weight saving and has quite a few disadvantages.
data.author: Brendan Hills

data.text: Every option has its place, I prefer the Hunka XL over the Elan hooped. If your camping in a midge free location like I was at the weekend, you just can‚Äôt beat a bivvy.
